content.question: If <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the function defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, the fraction with numerator 2 times the cosine squared of x, minus 1, and denominator cosine x minus sine x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, then <math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equivalent to which of the following?

choices.label: <math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, 2 times the cosine squared of x, minus 1, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, cosine x plus sine x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, cosine x minus sine x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator, the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, 2 times the cosine squared of x, minus 1, close parenthesis, and denominator, the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, cosine x minus sine x, close parenthesis, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi over 4, of, open parenthesis, cosine x plus sine x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
